titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Saturday.

On looking out of my window this morning, I found the ground as far as I could see again covered with snow. A light snow continued to fall till nearly noon, about 8 inches deep and without drifting, the atmosphere being calm— I called at the Department of State, and saw the chief Clerk Vail. The Secretary Forsyth was not there— I found a voluminous correspondence respecting the Pirates and murderers of the Plattsburg; with Saabye, and Forbes successively Consuls of the United States in Denmark; and between Forbes and Count Dohna then Prussian Minister in Denmark— I examined also my correspondence with Bagot, Antrobus and Canning, in several cases of the demand for the delivery up of persons charged with crimes— Among the rest the case of the man tried at Charleston S.C. taken in the Almeida— I was there nearly an hour and a half; and yet had not time to examine thoroughly the papers in any one of the cases; but I saw that many of them are very important for the discussion of the question of the delivery up of persons charged with crimes—Slaves—and deserters— The opinion of the Attorney General Wirt, against the delivery up in one case was referred to by me; but the opinion itself was not in the Letter Book, and I had not time to wait for a search for it among the files— The subject swells upon me as I look into it— I told Vail that I should move a call for the correspondence in the late cases of demands for surrender, but he was shy of giving me any information what they are— I went next to the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions J. L. Edwards, and found him at his desk— I left with him a Letter from Seth Sprague junr. and an affidavit respecting the pension claim of Lucy, widow of Melzar Stoddard— A Letter from Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn L.I. to the Commissioner Edwards, with a Certificate of the deputy Comptroller of New-York in support of the pension claim of widow Dinah Benson—and a Letter from the same Lewis and Pierce, with a Certificate from the Comptroller in support of the pension claim of Sibbel, widow of Craig Kelly.— Thence I went to the War Office and reminded the Secretary Poinsett of my recommendation of Mr Samuel A. Turner of Scituate for an Appointment of one of the annual Visitors at the West-Point Academy—of his answer that it was too late for that year, the appointment having been already made—but that Mr Turner would be remembered for the appointment of this year— He took down Mr Turner’s name, and said he should be remembered. I spoke to him also of the Memorial from the American Philosophical Society at Philadelphia praying an Appropriation for magnetic observations; and said I supposed its proper reference would be to the Military Committee— He said he thought a select Committee would be preferable. I met at the Department of State Felix Grundy—late Attorney General—now again Senator from Tennesee— Afternoon visit from Mr Dawson of Georgia and Mr Jenifer of Maryland.
2. IV:45. Sunday.

The Snow fell so level, and laid so light upon the ground, that I found a foot path, already beaten, on going this morning to the Presbyterian Church— Mr Wood preached from 2. Peter. 2.4. “For if God spared not the Angels that sinned, but cast them down to hell, and delivered them into chains of darkness, to be reserved unto judgment 5. And spared not the old world, but saved Noah, the eighth person, a preacher of righteousness bringing in the flood upon the world of the ungodly; 6. And turning the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah into ashes condemned them with an overthrow, making them an ensample unto those that after should live ungodly— 9. The Lord knoweth how to deliver the godly out of temptations, and to reserve the unjust unto the day of judgment to be punished”— A thorough going damnation Sermon—such as I have not heard for several years, and such as I would never willingly hear again— There is no religious doctrine which appears to me so revoltingly absurd as that which teaches that God Almighty created Man, with the foreknowledge and predestination of delivering him over to the dominion of the devil to all eternity—which exhorts man to repentance by laying it down, as an irrefragable truth that man can do nothing for himself, and that God sacrificed his own Son by an ignominious death, for the salvation of all mankind, ninety-nine of every hundred of whom are after all doomed to eternal misery— How is it possible to denominate the being who can be made to believe all this a rational animal? For these are not errors of ignorance; but errors of the most enlightened and most cultivated minds. It is in the exercise of the highest and acutest faculties of the human understanding, that Christian theologians arrive at these results, and they draw them from the holy Scriptures— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening service of the 4th. Sunday after the Epiphany, and preached from Zechariah 6.12 “And speak unto him saying, Thus speaketh the Lord of Hosts, saying behold the man, whose name is the BRANCH: and he shall grow up out of his place, and he shall build the temple of the Lord: 13— Even he shall build the temple of the Lord; and he shall bear the glory, and shall sit and rule upon his throne: and he shall be a priest upon his throne; and the counsel of peace shall be between them both.”— Mr Hawley has a peculiar propensity to select for his afternoon Sermons mysterious and obscure passages from the prophets without explaining them—of which this text is a signal example— The collect of the day was most impressive— “O God, who knowest us to be set in the midst of so many and great dangers, that by reason of the frailty of our nature we cannot always stand upright; Grant to us such strength and protection as may support us in all dangers, and carry us through all temptations, through Jesus Christ our Lord, Amen.” Of this strength and protection how great is my need! How hard the task to direct my course as the divine Spirit would enjoin! how faint the hope of accomplishing any useful purpose to close my career with the approbation of my maker.
3. VI. Monday
Fahrenheit 16.

Household occupations at home, delayed me this morning, so that it was 20 minutes past 11 when I reached the Committee room of the Committee of Manufactures— Four Members of the Committee had been there and without waiting for a Quorum had adjourned— I trust I shall take this as a lesson of punctuality. Whoever else may be tardy, the Chairman of a Committee should be to the minute at his post— In the House the result of the vote of last Friday for the five members of the cheap printing committee, was announced— Three of the five Black, the mover of the Resolution, John W. Davis of Indiana, and John H Prentiss of New-York elected— A second vote then absorbed nearly three hours of the time of the House— Rice Garland of Louisiana and George Evans of Maine were elected— Two days of the House have been consumed, in this viva voce election of a very useless Committee as I expect it will prove to be— The Speaker would have appointed the same men in five minutes.— This business being over, the house proceeded to vote for a chaplain, viva voce as before. There wereCandidates for this Office.votes were given in; and Joshua Danforth had the highest number 31—Mr Balch 29. Dr. Bates 29.24. and F. W. Boyd, nominated by Albert Smith, and for whom I voted 20.— The house then without taking a second vote adjourned— Mr Lawrence introduced to me two Officers of the Custom house at New-York, Mr Wasson and Mr Cairnes, who expressed a wish to confer with the Committee of Manufactures; and as they are obliged to leave the City on their return to New-York, the day after to-morrow, I notified the members of the Committee to meet to morrow morning at 11. O’Clock— Worthington was not in the house; and I could not find Nisbet— So I requested Mr Follansbee the door-keeper to give them notice at their lodgings.— At the suggestion of Mr Cushing I notified also the members from the Massachusetts Delegation in the House to attend a meeting in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, next Wednesday morning at 11 O’Clock, to consult together upon what we are to do with the abolition Petitions with which we are or hereafter may be charged— I notified them all, excepting W. S. Hastings whom I did not see in the House— Cushing said something of a Protest— There are objections to this, perhaps not insuperable, but some joint action of the whole delegation is surely advisable— I propose 1. To take a vote upon two sets of Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts— 2. To offer a Resolution that every member of the Delegation will by such means as he shall deem just and proper use his influence to obtain the rescinding of the new rule of the house 3. To suggest the expediency of publishing lists of all petitions refused to be received under the new rule of the house— 4. To propose a plan of co-operation with the members of other States friendly to the right of Petition— Thomas B. J. Frye dined with us— New Moon; sudden cold; and fine sleighing—
4. V. Tuesday.
Fahrenheit 10.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures at 11. Present Adams, Nisbet, Slade, Tillinghast, Dromgoole, Mitchell, Eastman, Davis— Absent, Worthington— Messrs. Wasson and Cairnes attended before the Committee, and testified to the enormous frauds practiced in the collection of the revenue— They appeared to be very respectable persons, and they spoke very earnestly in favour of the present Collector Jesse Hoyt, who no doubt appointed or patronizes them.— They said that in Swartwout’s time two of the Inspectors were bribed— That Mr Hoyt immediately after coming into office detected them, and they were removed— That the woolen trade is carried on almost exclusively by Agents of the Yorkshire Clothiers, utterly unprincipled men, who take out Commissions for testimony in England, which is any thing they require it to be— Mr Cairnes said it was his constant practice to appraise their goods from 15 to 50 per cent higher than their invoices— As to a remedy they thought of no other than an increase of the number of Appraisers, but they recommended to us to consult the collector Hoyt— We had not time to read the communications from the Secretary of the Treasury, and Mr Nisbet without hearing them read, thought the whole matter should be referred to the Committee on the judiciary. It was agreed however that we should meet Thursday Morning at ten O’Clock; and then consider whether the meetings of the Committee shall be reduced to once a week— At the House, Black the Chairman of the new cheap printing Committee a fiery tempered piece of inanity swelling with his dignity of Chairman of a select committee appointed by the house, palmed upon us by direction of the Committee two Resolutions—one that the Committee might be authorised to employ a clerk, with a flourish of their reasons for needing him, and of the facilities he would afford to their investigations—the other formally authorising them to summon witnesses before them, and to administer oaths to them— I was struck with the pomposity of the first resolution, but let it pass without notice— I observed that the second was worse than superfluous, by calling upon the house for authority to swear witnesses which every standing and select committee, possessed by express Law— I moved to strike out the second Resolution, and add to the first, power to the Committee to send for persons and papers— After some petulant resistance of Black and some impertinent sputtering of Ramsay, the bobtail of the Harrisburg mob, Black peremptorily called for the reading of the Law to which I had referred.— The acts of 1798 and 1817 were read— I said I hope the Chairman of the Committee now understands the Law, and my amendment was carried without a count— The Resolution was adopted, and the house proceeded to elect a chaplain— After the third ineffective vote Albert Smith withdrew the name of F. W. Boyd.— I then voted for Dr. Bates, who at the fifth vote was elected by 92 votes over Thomas Braxton who had 83. The time for daily receiving of petitions was continued to the 15th and after other business the house adjourned a quarter before four—
5. V. Wednesday
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 0.

So cold that I found it impossible to write before breakfast to my sore mortification— Meeting of the Massachusetts delegation in the house, at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures at 11. O’Clock— Present Adams, Baker, Briggs, Calhoun, Cushing, Hastings, Lincoln, Reed, Saltonstall;—absent, Lawrence, from indisposition, Parmenter and Henry Williams, purposely, to avoid concert with the rest. It was my wish to present the abolition petitions committed to my charge together with the rest— But the unanimous opinion of all the other members present was not to offer this day, any but that they called abolition petitions—that is to say that touched at all upon Slavery—but only business petitions— It was said that by avoiding the obstruction to the presentation of other petitions, we should not excite resentment, and that as the daily receipt of Petitions is continued until the 15th of this month we shall have ample time and occasion to present the Anti-slavery petitions between this time. I gave it as my opinion, that if we once let slip the opportunity of presenting the anti-slavery petitions, they would never allow us another.— I said that I had attended the meeting intending to propose measures of increasing concert and energy; to recover the prostrate right of petition; and I mentioned those that I minuted in this diary of the day before yesterday—but I said I would not set my face against the whole delegation and would accordingly abstain from presenting any anti-slavery Resolutions this day— Not even either of the two sets of Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts bearing upon Slavery— At the house I found Dr Bates closing his first prayer—Petitions were immediately called resuming the State of Massachusetts— Mr Lawrence presented one petition praying for the recognition of the Independence of Hayti—he moved its reference to the Committee of foreign Affairs— Linn Banks immediately moved to lay it on the table; which was carried by yeas and naysto 65. I presentedMemorials and Petitions among which were the Memorial of the American Philosophical Society; with the Letter of the Secretary of War Poinsett— the memorial of Alexander de Wattemare with the Letter from C. C. Cambreleng—referred to the joint Committee on the Library— The petition of W. M’Nally, and 1209. Seamen referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs— Two or three to the Smithsonian Committee, and others to the appropriate Committees— The other States were then called quietly till the Speaker called New-Jersey— Randolph then presented the Resolutions of the Legislature of New Jersey, remonstrating against the exclusion of the five members— Randolph enquired if the Speaker had not received the same resolutions from the Governor of the State, and was answered that he had; and declined presenting them.— This led to a blow up, in which the house got into a Chaos of confusion in the midst of which about 4. a motion to adjourn was carried— Miss Cutts took tea and spent the Evening here—
6. V. Thursday.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures at 10 O’Clock but it was full 11. before a quorum was formed— Present Adams, Nisbet, Mitchel, Eastman, Davis, Tillinghast, and Slade— Absent Dromgoole and Worthington.— The Documents received from the Secretary of the Treasury numbered from 1. to 4 were read; and demonstrated beyond all doubt enormous frauds in the collection of the revenue.— Ten or twelve additional memorials of manufacturers had been yesterday referred by the House to the Committee; but a Message from the President relating to the same frauds was yesterday referred to the Committee of Ways and Means.— Mr Nisbet was still desirous of requesting to be discharged from the further consideration of all the petitions, and to have them all referred to the Committee of Ways and Means I finally found myself roused in behalf of the manufacturing interest; and urged it upon the Committee, but I had no measure prepared to be proposed, and with the Committee yielded to the wish of Mr Nisbet to postpone the further consideration of the Petitions, till next Thursday— The same disposal was made of a Resolution offered by Tillinghast for reporting a bill to strike out the article of Pins, from the list of those exempted from duties—and also of the bill, introduced by Petrikin, to repeal the act of 14. July 1832, exempting rail-road iron from duty, and graduating the duty upon it. Mr Nisbet is exceedingly apprehensive of disturbing the compromise— Passing from the Committee room I found the house in Session, and the Clerk reading the answer of R. M. T. Hunter the Speaker, to the Governor of New Jersey declining to present the Resolutions of the Legislature of New-Jersey, because they had been transmitted to him, as a member of the house from Virginia, and not as speaker of the House. The resolutions were entered upon the journal of yesterday— Leadbetter moved to strike them out, and insert a narrative of dialogue and desultory debate— The motion was lost by yeas and nays, on a motion of John Reed to lay the amendment on the table 87 to 86— Then Randolph moved that the Resolutions should be printed—carried again by yeas and nays 92 to 90. though Pickens skulked— The call for Petitions was then continued through the remainder of the States and the Territories— At past 5. O’Clock a motion was made to adjourn, and upon taking the yeas and nays the vote was 21 to 27. All the rest of the members had deserted— Dromgoole whose face was of burnished brass moved a call of the house, but a renewed motion to adjourn then prevailed— Anderson of Kentucky had asked leave to present a Resolution to request the President to negotiate with Great Britain for a Treaty stipulation to deliver up fugitive slaves—but his proposal was immediately hushed.— Jameson of Missouri presented sundry Anti-abolition Resolutions of the Legislature of that State, which the Speaker said could not be received under the new rule— I asked if the fact of their being presented would appear upon the Journal—he said it would not— I said I should ask to be heard upon that question— Jameson said he did not wish to press the reception of them— The Speaker sent me a pencil note to enquire if I had thought of persons for the select committee which I moved yesterday—
7. VI:30. Friday.

Mrs Thornton our next door neighbour came in this morning and requested that Mrs Smith, Mrs John Adams and I would subscribe as witnesses to the making of her will, which we accordingly did— But she did not allow us to see what the will was, though I told her if we should ever be called to testify to the authenticity of the Will, we could only acknowledge our signatures and not any acquaintance with the contents— She preferred this rather than permit us to read the Will— After giving her due warning I acquiesced in her wish, and we all signed our names, as witnesses to the paper without knowing any thing of its contents. Immediately after the reading of the Journal, at the House John W. Jones Chairman of the Committee of Manufa Ways and Means, moved to suspend the rules, to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the Pension Appropriation Bill. He pretended there was an urgent necessity for the immediate passage of that Bill; but there was none at all— His only real motive was to evade the call of the States for Petitions—but he carried the suspension by a vote ofto 40. the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Levi Lincoln in the Chair— The pension appropriation Bill was taken up and read. I thought it would pass without observation, and a motion that the Committee should rise and report the Bill, when Marvin of New-York rose and started some objections to the practice of advancing large sums to the Pension Agents many Months before the payment of the Pensions becomes due Allowing the agent in the meantime the use of the money for his private speculations. Marvin moved no amendment, but Rice Garland followed him and moved as an Amendment that no advance should be made to any pension-agent more than one month before the payment shall become due— A long debate ensued till past 4. O’Clock, when the Committee rose and the house adjourned. Stanly alluded to the recent Bank and Ant-bank convulsions between the Legislature and Governor of Pennsylvania, which roused the wrathful blood of Beatty—the cool and shrewd sagacity of Sergeant, and the transparent changeable colours of Leet— Underwood not liking Rice Garland’s amendment proposed one of his own, to allow a per centage to the pension agents not to exceed 1500 dollars a year on their payments, and prohibiting them from using the money, while in their hands— These Pension agencies are among the foul corruptions engendered by Jackson’s war agains the bank of the United States— They glut the voracious rapacity of electioneering harpies, and are among the choice expedients of the Kinderhoek school in the art of compounding democratic majorities.
8. V:30— Saturday

Mr Force, the Mayor of the City, Dr Frederick Hall, and Mr Philip R. Fendall called upon me yesterday Morning at my House, and afterwards at the Capitol to enquire whether I shall be able to deliver the historical discourse which I conditionally promised during the present Session of Congress; and if so, when? The enquiry was distressing. I told them I was very apprehensive that I should find it impossible—but if it should prove otherwise I would give them notice before the last of April—with which they were satisfied— Three days ago, I received a Letter from Mr Minott Thayer, with a proof copy of my Discourse on Education delivered at Braintree on the 24th of last October printed by Perkins and Marvin at Boston; which I revised and enclosed it back— I called this day on the Secretary of the Treasury, with whom I found Mr John W. Jones, the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means— I spoke to the Secretary of the Petitions referred to the Committee of Manufactures from the Woollen Manufacturers, complaining of frauds in the collection of the revenue, and of the Message from the President on the same subject referred to the Committee of Ways and Means— I said I thought there might be some concert of proceeding between the two Committees and between both, and the department with regard to the measures to be adopted, and for myself I should be disposed, and believed the Committee would be so, to give effect to any plan which the Department might devise to remedy the acknowledged evil— He said it had sometimes happened that two Committees to which the same subject had been referred communicated with each other by Sub committees.— I spoke to him also upon the memorials, asking for a duty upon pins; and of Petrikin’s bill for laying a graduated duty upon railroad iron—he mentioned his report upon the subject, document 18 of the present Session which I had not noticed— I enquired what was the present condition of the Smithsonian fund— He said the interest upon the Arkansas and Michigan bonds had been regularly paid, and re-invested in Michigan bonds which had been purchased at 75 per cent. He said the Secretaries of War and of the Navy had been much annoyed to obtain payment of the interest to enable them to pay the Indian annuities and navy pensions. At the house the Speaker announced the call of Petitions as the order of the day— The petition from woollen manufacturers before presented by Mr Lawrence was referred without debate to the Committee of Manufactures. An instruction to the Committee of Ways and Means had been moved, to report a bill, appropriating 150000 dollars for continuing the Cumberland-road through each of the States of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois— Pickens moved to lay it on the table—lost—adjourned soon after 3.
9. V. Sunday.

The debate of yesterday upon the proposed instructions to the Committee of Ways and Means to report of an appropriation of 150000 for the continuation of the Cumberland road through each of the States of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois, presented some developments of the ostensible condition of parties; altogether delusive— Pickens moved to lay the motion of instructions upon the table— The western men were all as of course to make a clamorous resistance against this, but each one coloured by his party politics— Rariden of Indiana made a Harrison speech in favour of the appropriation, and Wick of the same State intreated and conjured Pickens, to withdraw his motion to lay on the table, that he might make a personal explanation; and he offered a pledge if Pickens would let him speak to renew the motion to lay on the table— Pickens after a decent portion of wavering, consented.— Biddle objected to this bargain for the exclusive occupation of the floor between two members— The Speaker said Pickens had a right to withdraw his motion to lay on the table; and he the Speaker could know nothing of any bargain between the two Gentlemen— From this decision Biddle appealed, but withdrew his appeal on the positive assurance from Wick that he only wanted to make a personal explanation— But this personal explanation, was a Kinderhoek speech in favour of the appropriation—to shew that however he agreed with Rariden in support of the road, it is as not for the same reasons— He was stop’d successively by White and Graves of Kentucky both of whom renewed Biddle’s appeal, and again withdrew it—while Pickens was all the time wavering, yielding and refusing to yield the floor several times— Wick finally made his speech and closed by renewing the motion to lay on the table— But after a call of the House the motion was rejected by yeas and nays 86 to 112. Biddle then took the floor, and gave such a scorching castigation as I have never before heard— Sampson Mason immediately followed but the house soon after adjourned—

This was a dull dark and gloomy day: sultry almost warm, with thick fog, and copious showers of rain in alternate succession At the morning service of the Presbyterian Church MrColton, a chaplain in the Navy preached from Luke 9.23. “And he said to them all, if any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me.” There might be thirty persons, men, women and children present— Mr Colton gave notice that owing to the inclemency of the weather, there would be no afternoon service there— And there was none at St. John’s Church. I read Mr J. K. Lothrop’s Sermon upon the destruction of the Steamboat Lexington by fire, and wrote on the report upon the Smithsonian bequest.
10. V:15 Monday.

Morning visit from Mr Lewis Johnson who informed me of the present condition of the claim of Mr John Otis of Barnstable as Administrator of his brother William Otis He said they had made one partial settlement in which he had received from the comptroller between 4 and 5000 dollars, which he had distributed pro tanto among William Otis’s creditors. They were now pressing for indemnity for the real estate— There was an unfavourable report but Mr Key hopes to prevail upon the Comptroller to reverse it— At the House the Speaker called upon the States for Resolutions according to the rule of the alternate Monday— There were three different rules of the house between which the Speaker this morning might take his choice— The order for daily receiving petitions till the 15th. which he ought to have taken— The rule of Saturday’s unfinished business of Saturday going into Committee of the whole on the Union, upon the pension appropriation Bill—and the alternate Monday call for Resolutions which I had suspected he would take and for which I was yet not quite prepared— The Resolutions offered from the Northern States were very few and unimportant—excepting two calls for correspondence relating to the North-eastern boundary question, from Maine— All the Resolutions offered were adopted without opposition till it came to me— I offered two— One a call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for all the investments in State Stocks of public monies—and the other upon the President for the demand of the Spanish Minister for the delivery up to him of the Africans captured in the Ship L’Amistad, and the correspondence with the Spanish Minister and with the District Attorney in Connecticut on the subject.— As calls upon the Executive these Resolutions lie over by the rule one day; but by the practice and the will of the Majority for an indefinite term of time, probably to the end of the Session, never to come up— I asked the house to take them up now—but Petrikin objected to both the Resolutions, and I acquiesced— Petrikin declared he would object to taking up now, all Resolutions required to lie over a day.— but he made exceptions for his friends.— Wise offered two Resolutions one of which was a call upon the Secretary of War for an account of the importation of bloodhounds— He said he was in possession of the fact officially from the Secretary of War himself. There was a great struggle to arrest Wise in making this Statement upon points of order; but he got it out in spite of them: Underwood brought forth an enormous budget of his proposed amendments to the Constitution; which Petrikin would not even allow to be printed— Bell brought forward his old bill to secure the freedom of elections, and the Bill to repeal the law limiting to 4 years the tenure of certain subordinate executive Offices. Cave Johnson made a desperate effort to refuse leave to introduce the first of these bills, but failed— The call for resolutions went through— Adjourned at 5. Miss Cutts dined with us.
11. V:30. Tuesday

Miss Pierce was here this morning, and requested me to ask Mr Underwood of Kentuckey to reclaim the papers relating to her and her Sisters claim from the Committee of Revolutionary claims of the house, so that they may be referred to a Committee of the Senate— Miss Pierce also exhibited to me receipts of several Articles of personal furniture which they have been compelled to pawn to defray their expenses.— I did speak to Underwood and he promised to procure the papers from the Committee— When the journal of yesterday, Davis moved to dispense with the reading of the Resolutions which was done— I enquired whether the decision of the speaker upon questions put by me, if the Slavery Resolutions of Rhett and Anderson of Kentucky were within the recent gag-rule, that they were not was entered upon the journal— It was not— The Speaker had dealt disingenuously with me in not telling me that it would not be— I moved to amend the journal by stating the fact of my enquiry and of the decision— The question was first put by rising and there were fifty six to forty four—no Quorum— I called for the yeas and nays which were ordered. Then Turney moved to lay the amendment on the Table— I called for the yeas and nays on this question and barely obtained them—36 only rising for them—the vote for laying them on the table was 116 to 52—my object was secured of having my question and the decision entered upon the journal; but my remarks were overheated and increased the majority for laying the amendment on the table— The Speaker then gave the floor to Samson Mason, upon Casey’s motion to instruct the Committee of Ways, and Means to report a Bill appropriating 450000 dollars for the continuation of the Cumberland road— I asked him if the receipt of petitions was not the order of the day—he said this was a case upon the reference of a Petition— Mason made a speech of about two hours to prove that the Government was bound, to make these appropriations by compact— He addressed himself chiefly to the South-Carolina nullifiers, and their Virginian auxiliaries with many shrewd remarks and cutting sarcasms— He was followed by Virgil D. Parris against the appropriation—a plain commonplace speech of less than half an hour, rather above the standard of the Orators capacity but the chief merit of which was its brevity— Ogden Hoffman then took the floor and moved an adjournment at short of four O’Clock which was carried— I paid a visit to Mrs Lawrence at Gadsby’s— Mr Lawrence, their Son, daughter and a Miss M’Leod were there— This Evening I read a long and very able article in White’s Southern Literary Messenger for January and February upon the Smithsonian bequest; written as I conjecture by Dr Dunglison— White the Editor of the Messenger sent it to me, and asks my opinion of it— But supposing Dunglison was not the author— My opinion of it might be different.
12. V:45 Wednesday

Two persons by the name of Stuart and Willy came as a Committee from the Franklin fire company with a subscription paper for a contribution to pay for an alarm bell which they said would cost from 200 to 250 dollars. As I was going to the Capitol I stopped at the Bank of Washington and received 100 half-eagles upon the check of the Speaker— Met Ogden Hoffman going to the house—and afterwards Abraham McClellan a member from Tennessee, who remarking upon the beautiful weather, a clear sky, and warm Sun, after a frosty night, said it would be fine weather upon his farm in Tennessee as for the running of the syrup from the sugar maple trees— He said there were great quantities of those trees in his part of the State, and that in a favourable season he had known 1000 pounds of sugar made from 150 trees— At the House the day was consumed by the delivery of three speeches upon the Cumberland road appropriation—first that of Hoffman which was in his usual style of classical eloquence— He was in favour of the appropriation for the Cumberland road; but not for instructing the Committee of Ways and Means, until, the President or the Secretary whether the omission of the appropriation for the Cumberland road from the estimates of the present year was intentional or undesigned— He read passages from the Message warning Congress not to make any appropriation beyond those exhibited in the Estimates; and giving a significant hint, that if they do, he will veto the Bills for their extravagance and boasting that if the estimates of the Departments are not exceeded the public expenses of this year will be five Millions less than they were the last year— He then referred to the appropriations already much exceeding five Millions, proposed by friends of the administration, not even hinted at in the estimates; and he exposed the fraud in the Message, of suppressing and of the estimates in omitting millions upon millions of the expenses, which it was known congress must and would authorize, so as to throw upon Congress the Odium of extravagant expenditure measured by the amount of the appropriations, and boast of his own rigorous economy measured by the amount of the purposely curtailed estimates and the urgent and threatening admonition to Congress to keep closely within them. Hoffman was followed by David Hubbard in a violent, crabbed speech of common place declamation against the appropriation; and he by Tilghman A Howard of Indiana in a very able and eloquent, but cunning and disingenuous speech in its favour— Howard is a young man of fine talents, and now a Candidate for election as Governor of the State. He said he had made 75 stump speeches to obtain his election to Congress—and this was a stump speech for the Office of Governor— Pickens moved an amendment, and there was a question between him and Proffit about the floor— Adjourned after 4—
13. V:15 Thursday

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures at 10 this morning— Present Adams, Nisbet, Davis, Mitchell, Eastman, Tillinghast, and Worthington— Upwards of 20 memorials; complaining of the frauds in the collection of the revenue, from the woollen manufactures had been referred to the committee since their last meeting— And an additional communication had been received by me from the Secretary of the Treasury which I now communicated to the meeting.— After much conversation at my suggestion, Mr Nisbet and myself were appointed a sub-committee to confer with a sub-committee of the Committee of Ways and Means, upon the remedy to be provided for the frauds on the revenue; to see if the two Committees can agree upon one measure— Sundry Memorials for laying duties on silk—postponed; on putty—laid on the table— A Memorial for revising the Tariff, and requiring cash payments—laid on the table— Mr Tillinghast’s Resolution for reporting a bill to strike out pins from the articles exempted from duty—postponed.— Petrikin’s Bill to levy a duty upon rail-road iron postponed— A memorial for prohibiting the sale of Ardent Spirits to the Soldiers and Sailors of the Army and Navy—postponed— A petition from Strickland and two other Architects for remission of duties upon a Book of American works published by them in London—postponed— There are five members of the Committee adverse to the manufacturing interest—Dromgoole, Nisbet, Eastman, Davis and Worthington— Dromgoole and Slade were absent this morning— In the House, after an attempt by Russell to get one hour for reports of Committees, which succeeded for to-mor Pickens took the floor, and spoke about an hour and a half; as usual repeating with pompous inanity the ideas of John C. Calhoun— Against the appropriation to restore the Constitution to its original principles— And offering by way of substitution to give away all the public lands to the States in which they are situated— This is the bribe offered by Slavery to the cupidity of the West— He was followed by Proffit the successor of Ratliff Boon, and politically at his antipodes— The Southern and Western contested elections sharpen the wits and improve greatly the talent of public speaking— Proffit, with little education, with no learning; with backwoodsman’s roughness of manner, with open hearted candour, and with an instinctive tact in debate, is one of the most powerful Speakers in the house— Marvin of New-York succeeded and offered an Amendment which he supported by a Speech of half an hour, which he modified at the request of Daniel D. Barnard, who moved the adjournment and has the floor for to-morrow—
14. V:30. Friday

At C. J. Nourse’s Office I exchanged 50 half-eagles, and deposited 260 dollars bills of the Bank of the United States at the Bank of Washington—and there took up the 22 Sovereigns that I had deposited there— At the House D. D. Barnard had the floor on the Cumberland-road question, Francis E. Rives moved to suspend the rules, that he might offer a Resolution authorizing the Committee of Elections to have all the papers laid before them printed for the use of the house. One hour of this morning had ben yesterday fixed at the motion of David Russell, Chairman of the Committee of Claims, to receive Reports from Committees— But this motion of Rives was made not from the Committee of Elections, but from their minority— I had been informed yesterday by Brockway that it would be made; and that its object was to get the subject again prematurely before the house to ground a motion to admit the spurious members from New-Jersey— There was a call of the House— Onlymembers answered to their names and further proceedings in the call were suspended— Rives’s motion to suspend the rules failed, though sustained by a majority 83 to 72— Reports from the Committee of Elections was called.— John Campbell, Chairman of the Committee of Elections, offered from the Committee a Resolution authorizing the Committee to have their journal printed— Rives moved his Resolution to have all the papers before the Committee printed for the use of the house as an amendment, and called for the previous question—but before it could be ascertained that there was a second to the previous question, the hour expired; the orders of the day were called and Barnard took the floor on the Cumberland road. He made an excellent speech of about two hours, receiving little attention from the house, now thoroughly weary of this subject; and highly excited by the return upon them of the New Jersey election through the schism in the Committee of Elections. Barnard was followed by Isaac E. Crary of Michigan one of the most desperate disorganizers of the House, who in a speech of two hours took one of them in reading the despatches of General William H. Harrison, during the last War with Great Britain with a perpetual military Commentary as he went along—to prove that Harrison was a wretched general in answer to Proffit’s panegyric upon him yesterday— Patrick G. Goode then took the floor, and after an ineffectual attempt of Curtis to adjourn over to Monday, moved about 5. an adjournment which was carried. Wise shewed me a Letter from a Clergyman in Virginia named L. L Smith; about my religious opinions—and afterwards his answer—
15. VI. Saturday.

Mr Wilcocks was here this morning, and made enquiries about lots of land, which he wanted to lease for the purpose of raising garden vegetables upon them. I referred him to Mr Frye— He says he has obtained a Clerkship in the adjutant General’s Office. I received by last evening’s mail a Letter enclosing a remonstrance, and a string of resolutions adopted by a numerous popular meeting atNew-Jersey against the exclusion by the house of Representatives of five of the six commissioned members from that State, from their Seats.— The remonstrance and Resolutions were likewise enclosed in a packet addressed to that delegation, which I was requested to deliver to them, and did this morning deliver to Mr Randolph— It was desired that if they thought it expedient that a member other than one of themselves should present the remonstrance to the house the duty should devolve upon me— And the measure was suggested to them, but left to their discretion of withdrawing altogether and returning home There was also a vote of thanks to Wise, Barnard, Stanly, myself and others for our exertions in sustaining the rights of New-Jersey in the house— But the committee of elections have postponed the consideration of this case for two Months to give the parties time for collecting their evidence, and Randolph told me that the five members were all gone— This state of things was altogether different from that under which the remonstrance and resolutions of the meeting were adopted— I advised Randolph not to withdraw, and thought his colleagues could not at this time without appearing to abandon their cause— I advised him also to write to Dr Condict, and to present the remonstrance himself; but said I would present it if he so preferred— He said he scarcely knew what to do, and appeared dejected— It is plain that the same rotten majority which committed the first outrage will carry it through and not only expel the five members duly elected, but admit the five spurious pretenders.— In the house, after some preliminary squabbling, Goode of Ohio made a sensible Speech of three hours upon the defence of General Harrison against Crary’s attack of yesterday— Corwin then took the floor and reminded me of Apollo skinning Marsyas.— When he came to the Cumberland road about 4. O’Clock he moved to adjourn— Carried— I took books out of the library and visited my Colleague John Reed, at Hyatt’s, in bed with an intermittent fever— Met Mr Halstead there. Evening visits from a person named Buffum asking a contribution for a School in New Jersey which I declined, and from P. R. Fendall to whom I returned the Books and Papers of David Christy who is publishing a historical Library at Oxford, Ohio.
16. V:30. Sunday.

Mr Meehan the Librarian of Congress yesterday told me that in the violent storm of the Night before last, one arm of the emblematical statue of America, in the Pediment over the entrance door of the Hall of the House of Representatives, my design so beautifully executed by Persico, had been blown away, and came down with a tremendous crash— He said the group was of free stone— I said it was ominous— He said he hoped not— But he was mistaken as to the Statue mutilated.— It is not the figure, but that of Justice which has lost her right arm, nearly to the elbow— Still more ominous; and painfully significant of the condition of the Hall within, where Justice has emphatically lost her right arm— This morning I attended public worship at the Presbyterian Church, where Mr Colton the chaplain in the Navy preached from Proverbs 22.6. [“]Train up a child in the way he should go: and when he is old, he will not depart from it.”— The whole system of good-education, and of parental instruction seems to be embraced in these few words. Mr Colton’s discourse was addressed chiefly to Parents— Plain—practical—urgent—eloquent by the very omission of all the arts of eloquence— He dwelt very earnestly upon the duty and efficacy of maternal instruction exemplified in the conversion and beatification of John Newton, of whom he related that he was converted from that most infamous of all occupations (so he called it) a slave trader on the coast of Africa— Then it was by the agency and instructions of John Newton, that Thomas Scott, the author he said of the best commentary on the bible that had ever been published, had been formed—and Thomas Scott had been the instructor of Dr Morrison the translator of the Bible into the Chinese language— All this good he said had been accomplished, by the prickings of conscience of John Newton while pursuing the piracy of the Slave trade, but remembering the tender admonitions of his mother— Mr Colton gave notice, that there would be a meeting of the members of the Society at half past four O’Clock next Tuesday afternoon, to consult together upon what is to be done concerning the present condition of the Church and congregation— Mrs Frye was here after the morning service at St. John’s, but would not stay to dine— After dinner I attended at St. John’s where Mr Boyd read the evening service for Septuagesima Sunday, and preached from Mark 1.15. [“]and saying, the time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of God is at hand: repent ye, and believe the gospel.” I read the Sermon of Mr Furness of Philadelphia upon that awful calamity the burning of the Steamboat Lexington one of those events at which the heart sickens, and imagination is incapable of conceiving why it was permitted by omnipotent goodness— Dr Follen, and Mrs Russel Jarvis with her two daughters were among the victims— What can I say; and what must I think! that God is good, and that myself am blind— The day slipped away almost unheeded; but the evening until midnight was engrossed by the report on the Smithsonian bequest.
17. V:30. Monday

Mr Samuel Lawrence called on me at 10. O’Clock this morning, by appointment made with him in the lobby of the House last Saturday— I had received from the Secretary of the Treasury a long bill, prepared by Jesse Hoyt collector of the Port of New-York, for the punishment and suppression of the frauds on the revenue; of which the manufacturers complain to be submitted to the Committee of Manufactures— Mr Lawrence has read and approves Mr Hoyt’s Bill; but wishes the addition to it of two or three Sections, drawn up by Mr Fletcher, and which have reference to frauds practised at Boston by a process different from that which has been used at New-York and which are to be remedied by Mr Hoyt’s Bill— Mr Lawrence read to me, and promised me a copy of his proposed additional Sections, and said he would attend at the Meeting of the Committee next Thursday.— Mr Radcliff was also here, and reported progress upon his new memorial for opening a Canal across the isthmus of Panama— It was presented to the Senate by Dr Linn of Missouri, and referred to the Committee of Commerce of which W. R. King of Alabama is chairman— Mr King is not very favourably disposed to the project, and thinks the first thing to be done is to secure by Legislative enactment the assent of the Government of central America to the undertaking.— But Mr Radcliff thinks Mr Van Buren is at heart inclined to the scheme; a great favourite of his named O’Sullivan, one of the Editors of the Democratic review, having published in that Miscellany two Articles recommending the Canal, and reprinted them in a pamphlet of which Mr Radcliff gave me a copy— He said he was about to return in two or three days to New-York— At the House John W. Jones Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means moved to suspend the rules for a resolution to take up the pension-bill at one O’Clock to-morrow— Waddy Thomson objected which forced the taking of the yeas and nays 166 to Waddy’s solitary no— The Resolution was adopted without opposition— Sergeant squeezed in a report from the judiciary Committee of a bill from the Senate amendatory to that for taking the Census— Governor Lincoln insisted that this was the alternate Monday for receiving petitions; but in vain— The Speaker decided that Corwin had the floor; but Corwin took a vote of the house which gave the same result; though Governor Lincoln was unquestionably right— Corwin then delivered in the space of three hours one of the most eloquent Speeches ever pronounced in that house, and was followed by Mr Bell of Tennessee against the appropriation—about one hour— A motion was then made that the daily receipt of petitions, should be continued till the first of March—the vote was twice taken; the second time by tellers but there was in both cases no Quorum to vote— So the house adjourned; about half past four— Corwin’s speech was admirable, but not quite equal to that part of it, which he delivered on Saturday— The Philippics—the Oration for the Crown; all the most splendid Orations of Cicero are personal— The highest flights of eloquence are always personalities—
18. IV:30 Tuesday.

A Mr Wilson called on me this morning, belonging to the Congregation of the second Presbyterian Church, and expressed the wish that I would attend their meeting this afternoon, which was to invite Mr Wood to settle with them as their pastor, or to authorise the use of my name if favourable to him— I could not attend the meeting; held while the House of Representatives were in Session, but I authorised Mr Wilson to use my name to say that if it be the pleasure of the Society to settle Mr Wood, it will be with my entire acquiescence and good will— I had a visit from Rufus King, son of Edward King deceased, and James G King junr, son of James G. King, both grandsons of my old, and long departed friend Rufus King— The young man who bears his name was graduated last summer at Harvard University, and is a member of the law school there— His mother is a daughter of Thomas Worthington, one of the first Senators of the United States from the State of Ohio, with whom I sat several years in that body— He brings me now a Letter of Introduction from President Quincy speaking of him in terms of high commendation— When I reached the capitol I found the House in Session, taking the yeas and nays, on a motion to suspend the rules for a resolution to continue the daily right to present petitions till the first of March— The Clerk was just at the name of Allen when I entered, so that by the rule of the house, I could not vote, though Mr Dawson of Georgia, who entered the House with me could and did— The suspension was lost for want of the two thirds; the vote standing 91 to 66. The Resolution reported by Campbell Chairman of the Committee of Elections for the printing of their journal, with the amendment offered by Cave Johnson to print all their papers, was now taken up and Campbell made a speech relating much of what had occurred in the Committee, in which he holds the balance between the parties of 4 and 4 so that he declared himself responsible for every thing they have done. Campbell finished his Speech but the question on his Resolution was not taken; for the hour of one came, and Jones, chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, called for the special order of the day, the Pension Appropriation Bill— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Levi Lincoln in the Chair— The amendments proposed by Rice Garland, and White of Kentucky were debated with great ardour, nearly four hours and rejected, Garland’s without a count— White’s by Tellers 52 to 78 The Committee reported the Bill without amendment— On its passage to a third reading the yeas and nays were called. There was no negative vote but only 135 about 50 members present did not vote— The Bill was then read a third time; passed without opposition; and at half past 5 the house adjourned— Rain and thick warm fog— It was dark when I reached home.
19. V:30. Wednesday.

By dint of untiring industry, I wrote the journal of yesterday before breakfast this morning and more than a page of the Smithsonian report before going to the Capitol— I found the House in Session, the Clerk reading the Journal of yesterday— The first thing taken up was the Resolution offered by Campbell Chairman of the Committee of Elections, for the printing their journal and other papers with the amendment of Cave Johnson for the printing of all their papers, for the use of the house; which amendment Campbell this morning said he was instructed by the Committee to accept— Millard Fillmore had the floor from yesterday— He is a member of the Committee, and commenced a Speech against Cave Johnson’s amendment in which he related sundry transactions in the Committee and read a Resolution adjourning the farther consideration of the subject till the 12th. of April, giving the parties the interval to collect further testimony— Fillmore was exposing the motive to this movement—the design to force of report from the Committee and a decision upon the New-Jersey Election, without waiting for the testimony.— I have foreseen from the beginning that this would be the last resort of the Administration party, and that they would end as they began by arbitrary decision instead of adjudication— When Fillmore began to read the Resolution of the Committee, Petrikin made a point of order insisting that he should make no allusion to any thing that took place in the Committee; and this point of order as usual threw the house into confusion— The Speaker decided that it was not in order to refer to any thing that took place in Committee, and therefore that Fillmore must not read the resolution— Fillmore appealed and withdrew his appeal— A motion was made that he should have leave to proceed, and it was coming to a call of yeas and nays— I then appealed from the Speaker’s decision—debate followed; and at 1. O’Clock the Orders of the day were called— There was a struggle to continue the debate on the New-Jersey election, but the Orders of the day prevailed—

A Bill from the Senate making an appropriation to remove a raft from the red river of Arkansas was first in order, upon which Biddle had moved a reference to a Committee with Instructions; upon which he made a speech of an hour and a half against the appropriation— Answered by Cross of Arkansas, and by Rice Garland— Beatty of Pennsylvania about 4. O’Clock took the floor and moved to adjourn which was carried— Biddle’s Artillery is heavy but he wastes his powder in petty warfare— The Speaker came, and spoke to me of my appeal from his decision; in which he said he wished me to persist. Mary Cutts dined with us, her brother here. And Charles J. Ingersoll.
20. V. Thursday

Fire in my chamber intermitted— Soap-Stone. Last evening we had a visit from Mr Hawley. I finished this morning the draught of a Report on the Smithsonian bequest Bill, to be submitted to the Committee; and left it with Mr D. D. Barnard at his lodgings.— I have requested him to read it, and to suggest any alterations, additions or omissions which may occur to him, as advisable before I present it to the Committee— Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures, at which Mr Samuel Lawrence attended— Present Adams, Nisbet, Tillinghast, Mitchell, Davis, Eastman, Dromgoole, Slade— I had received from the Secretary of the Treasury, the draught of a Bill, in 13. Sections, prepared by the Collector and District Attorney U.S. at New-York, with explanatory remarks upon each Section, and 3. Additional Sections offered by Mr Samuel Lawrence; and drawn up by Mr Fletcher of Boston— The Bill was read by Mr Mitchell, and the explanatory observations upon each section, by me, Section by Section— A motion was then made that the Chairman do report the Bill—but to this Eastman and I myself objected, without further examination of its contents. It was therefore agreed to meet again, Monday Morning at 10.— The Speaker sent for me to his chamber, to adjust the phraseology of his decision and my appeal made yesterday, which was done— This appeal was the first business of the day— I had the floor, and after the usual struggle to get other business before the house, I briefly stated my reasons for making the appeal— Linn Banks made a Speech to sustain the decision— Concurring with me in the abusive practice of majorities in the application of the rules; perfectly willing that Fillmore should read the resolution of the Committee upon which the point of order had been taken, he still thought it all important that the majority should hold their grasp upon this engine of power— He asked me to withdraw my appeal, and at the same time moved to lay it on the table— But withdrew his motion upon being reminded that if the appeal was laid on the table the Resolution would of course follow it— Pope and Briggs replied to Banks; the hour expired and the orders of the day were called— Graves moved a suspension of the rules to introduce a Resolution of investigation into a dirty transaction of the Postmaster General, but failed by a vote of 118 to 83. not two thirds.— An amendment to the Pension Appropriation Bill, made by the Senate was concurred in— The red river raft Bill was passed over, and the Bill amendatory of that for taking the sixth census was debated in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Linn Banks in the Chair— W. B. Carter introduced mal-a-propos the character of the Marshal of East-Tennessee, which was sharply defended, with retort very uncourteous by Watterson and M’Lellan of that State— Petrikin offered a ridiculous preamble censuring the last Congress for incompetency, in passing an imperfect Bill— Dawson and Wise, warmly opposed this preamble and Dromgoole with much intercession prevailed upon Petrikin to withdraw it— The bills were reported and the house shortly before 6. adjourned.
21. IV:30. Friday

Last Evening and this morning were consumed in assorting endorsing and filing Letters received since the entrance of this month, which had become numerous— At the House after much effort particularly of David Russell Chairman of the Committee of Claims to obtain leave for the Committees to report; my appeal from the Speaker’s decision was taken up, and the decision confirmed by an unflinching party vote.

After this decision Fillmore commenced resuming his Speech; but Petrikin insisted that having been declared out of order he could not without special permission from the house, proceed— Here was another point of order; and another brawling debate till past one O’Clock— It was apparent that the administration party intend to force a decision upon the New-Jersey election without waiting for the testimony— They had come prepared to force it this day—so that when after the expiration of the hour, the call was made for the orders of the day, the house refused by yeas and naystoto do so— Then they contended that the question upon Cave Johnson’s amendment to the Resolution offered by Campbell was still under debate— And so the Speaker at first decided—but the reverse had been repeatedly decided before— And Fridays and Saturdays being expressly assigned for private business, the Speaker finally decided that this order of business is a different thing from the orders of the day, and can be set aside only by a majority of two thirds— After much manoeuvering to bring him round again, Holleman, most respectfully took an appeal from his decision which was confirmed by yeas and nays 116 to 64— Private Bills from the Senate were taken up; and while one of them was under discussion, I went into the Senate chamber, and gave to Mr Mouton a Senator from Louisiana, to whom Mr Preston of South-Carolina introduced me, the copy of the Petition of 611 Masters and Officers of Vessels at New-Orleans, for the repeal of the Naturalization Laws; which they have requested me to present to the House— I told Mr Mouton that although I should present the petition, I should not support it— He said it might be advisable to modify the Naturalization Laws but not to repeal them— On returning to the House I found them upon the Bill for continuing the office of Commissioner of Pensions; and Proffit on the floor making a regular retrenchment Speech, upon a motion to reduce the Salary of the Commissioner from 3000 to 2500 dollars a year— Then a wrangling match between Proffit and Graves and Albert Smith, about the relative extravagance of the whig and democratic parties, in which Duncan manifested a convulsive passion to take a part—he finally about half past four O’Clock moved the adjournment which was carried— Briggs came to my Seat and asked me how I should vote on the question to reduce the Commissioner’s Salary— I said against it— He said he believed he should do the same.— I said the whole Scheme would prove a humbug—
22. V: Saturday

Mr John Codman, a young man from Boston, brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Abbott Lawrence— He says his father resided at New-York, and was a brother of the Codman’s of Boston.— He said he was pursuing some revolutionary pension claim for a soldier who enlisted about the time of the dark day—and asked me if I could tell him when that was.— I told him it was in May 1780— I thought the 25th.— But afterwards I found in the Massachusetts Register for 1836. it was on the 19th.— In looking over my files of Letters I found in one of them a Petition for a Revolutionary Pension which I had over looked— And six or seven cases of applications for information at the Departments— I took four of them to the Pension Office and left them with the Commissioner Edwards for answers to the Enquiries— I met there John C. Clark of New-York, Isaac Fletcher of Vermont with his Son; and Governor Lincoln.— And the Secretary of War sent for Mr Edwards to go to him; so that I could not make the enquiries personally of him— I called upon the Secretary himself, who was engaged—but one of the waiters shewed me into his private chamber where he soon came to me— I left with him the Letter of the Revd. William M. Cornell of Quincy recommending W. H. Wood, son of Henry Wood for admission as a Cadet at West-Point this or the next year— He asked if there was not one from my Congressional District— I said there was—Zealous B Tower—appointed at my nomination and twice successively reported as the head of his Class. But he is to be graduated in 1841 and then there will be a vacancy of a cadet from that District.— Mr Poinsett said he would have the name of W. H. Wood, entered as a Candidate upon my recommendation for 1841. and he kept the recommendatory Letter of Mr Cornell to me, to be put on the files— I spoke to him of the Memorial from the American Philosophical Society, which I have presented to the House, and of its reference to a select Committee.— I asked him if he could furnish me with a copy of the circular from the English Royal Society concerning combined magnetical observations— He said he had it not; but thought he could procure it, by writing to Mr Du Ponceau— From the War Department I went to the Department of State, and conversed with Mr Forsyth— I found that the distribution of the Alliance Prize Money, belonged to neither of those Departments, but to the Treasury— I had also much conversation with Mr Forsyth respecting the case of the Africans captured in the ship L’Amistad; and of the demands for delivering up persons upon the demand of foreign Governments— He said the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in the case of Holmes was to be delivered this day.— I had intended to devote a part of this day to returning visits of which I owe a multitude— But when I came back from the Departments it was past 2 O’Clock—too late for visiting— I only left a Card for Mr Grinnell at his lodgings.
23. V: Sunday.
Fire yesterday and this day—part of each day—

I attended public worship this morning at the Presbyterian Church where Mr Wood preached from Psalm 12.6 [“]The words of the Lord, are pure words; as silver tried in a furnace of earth purified seven times.” It was a discourse upon the excellency of the Bible; and incomparably the most pleasing to me of any that I have ever heard from Mr Wood— He spoke of its prophetical, its historical and its doctrinal character. well—of Abraham, the father of the faithful—of Isaac—of Jacob. of Moses, and All the prophets—of Jesus and the Apostles.— He laid down in terms as clear and explicit as the gospel of Christ, that the salvation of Sinners depended upon their belief in Jesus, manifested by works— And surely that is the doctrine of the new Testament— Faith is belief, and the difficulty is to understand how far our faith depends upon our own will.— Belief is an operation of the immortal soul— It is a property belonging only to man of all the animal creation— Faith is confidence in the word of another—and Faith is fidelity to your own word— These two properties are entirely distinct from each other; and yet seem to be indissolubly connected together— A man must be devoted to Truth himself, to believe in the truth of another—and by the reverse of the position— He who believes in the truth of another will always be himself faithful— But whom and what are we to believe? Experience of the world, teaches distrust and confidence is a plant of slow growth in an aged bosom, as was said by Lord Chatham. Belief therefore, to be rational presupposes a diligent search after truth, and a sound judgment.— Mr Wood gave notice that divine service would hereafter be regularly performed here after in that Church at the usual hours every Sunday. He was chosen last Tuesday Pastor of the Church— After dinner at St. John’s Church. Mr F. W. Boyd read the Evening service for Sexagesima Sunday, and preached from John 5.40. “And ye will not come to me, that ye might have life.” How stands the grammar of that sentence?— John Sergeant was there and walked home with me, but would not come in— I am so absorbed in temporalities that I prepared an estimate of the cost of an Observatory; to be appended to the Report on the Smithsonian bequest Bill— This was suggested by Mr D. D. Barnard on returning the manuscript Report, which I communicated to him, and which he approves— Miss Cutts was here this Evening. I received 11 Petitions, and sundry Letters, among which two from Lewis and Pierce at Brooklyn, Long Island, one from N. F. Williams of Baltimore, one from Ibrahim Bartlett of Quincy, which will require my attention as speedily as possible—
24. VI— Monday.

Going to the Capitol this morning I met a man named Henry Wilson, who said he was of Quincy and gave me a parcel of dirty papers which he pretended would vouch his claim as an invalid pensioner for service during the last War, with Great-Britain and consequent disability.— I told him to come to my house to-morrow morning.— Miss Elizabeth Pierce was also here this morning, and said that Mr Underwood had advised to leave their claim to the decision of the Committee of the House.— Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Davis, Nisbet, Mitchell, Tillinghast and Eastman— Absent Dromgoole, Worthington and Slade— Six Sections of Mr Hoyt’s Bill were read, discussed and amended, and one of the Sections struck out— The discussion upon the 7th. was begun and left unfinished when the time for the meeting of the house came— This was the alternate Monday for receiving Resolutions—but upwards of two hours were consumed upon a motion of John W. Jones to make the new Treasury Note Bill for to-morrow the special order of the day— He moved to suspend the Rules but failed by yeas and naystoThen Campbell moved that the Committee of Elections should have leave to send for persons and papers in the two contested cases of Charles J. Ingersoll against Naylor, and of the Memorial against the election of Osmyn Baker for the 6th. District of Massachusetts— There was a wrangling debate upon this Resolution terminated only by the previous question, and two votes of yeas and nays— The leave was given in both cases.— At last about half past 2. The call for Resolutions commenced with the Territory of Iowa— Several of the members attempted to squeeze in Petitions memorials and Resolutions of State Legislatures, and Rariden of Indiana moved a suspension of the rules to let in a reference to a Committee of some favourite of his own, but failed like all the rest— The Speaker was calling the State of Kentucky, when after 4 O’Clock a motion to adjourn was carried— Casey had moved a suspension of the Rules for a Resolution to continue four days longer the daily reception of Petitions, but he failed; and his real object was not to receive petitions but to bring up again the Cumberland road debate.— Granger told me he had received several memorials praying for the rescinding the rule of 28 Jany. and enquired if I had any— I had— And said as his State would be called before mine, I wished him to move the Resolution to rescind; which if no other member should do before the Call of my State I should do myself— He said he would— I had one memorial from Boston, signed by more than 100 names—none of whom were personally known to me— I took it to Mr Lawrence, who said he knew many of the signers—respectable men— I came home sick with a new feverish Catarrh— No dinner— Evening better.
25. V:30. Tuesday.

This man, who says he is from Quincy, and that he has formerly made shoes for my father and for me, came to persuade me to draw and present for him a petition for an inverlead pension— He says he enlisted as a soldier during the last War with England and as a Sailor sundry times since— The last time at Baltimore in October 1829. when he was examined and certificated sound— In April 1830: he was discharged for disability; but his discharge did not attest that his disability occurred while on public service— He thought this should be inferred from the fact of a rupture— He had quarreled with Commodore Chauncey under whom he served, and with the surgeon, who treated him, both now dead, and had not a shadow of evidence to shew his claim to an invalid pension. I told him if he would procure a deposition from any credible person that his rupture occurred while he was on the service, I would draw and present a petition for him, and he went away in search of a witness.— I called at the Pension Office, and left with Mr Edwards a Letter from Lewis and Pierce to him, and one to me, with papers relating to the pension claims of Francis Conklin, Phebe Reeve, and Sarah Lennington—with Conklin’s pension certificate to be exchanged for one of increased amount— A Letter from Jonathan Parker of Plympton, and one from William Ellis of Dedham— Then I called on the Secretary of War and enquired at what time the visitors of the Military Academy at West-Point were first appointed and what Instructions were given them— I had some conversation with him upon the Smithsonian bequest Bill— At the House the day was consumed upon the Resolution offered by Campbell Chairman of the Committee of Elections, and the amendment proposed by Cave Johnson— The house by a close party vote 95 to 91. sustained the decision of the Speaker that Fillmore having been pronounced out of order for offering to read a Resolution adopted in the Committee of Elections, could not proceed in his Speech without permission of the House— They then passed a vote of permission, which he respectfully declined— Fisher another member of the Committee then spoke about an hour of invective upon the proceedings of the majority of the Committee—repeatedly called to order, and pronounced out of order by the Speaker but suffered to go on as he pleased— Crabbe a member of the Committee on the other side attempted to speak, but was silenced. Truman Smith of Connecticut another whig member took the floor near four O’Clock, and after he had spoken about half an hour upon a second taking of yeas and nays the house adjourned— Campbell absent from the house sick— Returning from the capitol I met and walked home with Miss Cutts.
26. V. Wednesday.

Purchased a pair of Carriage horses, for which I paid 250 dollars— Exchanged at Charles Nourses Office 90 half-eagles for 472:50 in U.S. Bank Bills, which I deposited at the Bank of Washington— There I took a Draught on the Merchants Bank in Boston in favour of Ibrahim Bartlett Cashier of the Stone Bank at Quincy, for which I gave 79:13. Nourse allows 5 per cent for discount on the Bank Bills and the Bank takes 5 1/2. The Smithsonian bequest Bill Committee met at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures at 10 O’Clock—present Adams, Shepard, Garland, Barnard, Corwin and Lewis—absent Ogle, Smith of Maine and Campbell of South-Carolina, who is sick—confined to his chamber, and was not notified.— I presented my Report, of which I briefly stated the contents. The Committee authorised me to present to the house and move to be printed— The additional Sections, and the Estimates were read and authority was given me to report them with the Bill— Also the Messages of 6 and 7. December 1838. and any other Document at my discretion. Dixon H. Lewis proposed to report a Counterproject for the establishment of an agricultural School, on Fleischman’s plan— It was agreed that he should present to the House his counter projet at his leisure, and that it should also be printed.— Lewis declared his aversion to the acceptance of the bequest, which he said only gave trouble to Congress by diverting their attention and consuming their time upon subjects not suitable for their Legislation— He asked again that a motion might be made to have Fleischman’s Memorial at the last Session of Congress reprinted; which was agreed to— In the House, the New-Jersey election case was brought up at once. Johnson of New-York, moved a Resolution for an investigation into a dirty bargain by the Clerk of the house given to Langree— But Truman Smith of Connecticut had the floor and declined yielding it— He made a Speech of three hours in answer to Fisher’s most disingenuous Speech of yesterday— Smith was followed by Rives of Virginia about half an hour—very angry and very dull— Then by Weller of Ohio, one of the blustering bullies of the house— Noisy and surly— He began by saying that there had been enough said on the subject, and that he would move the previous question—and then he launched into standing common-place declamation and vulgar abuse, till he acknowledged that he could not fairly move the previous question— Crabbe a whig member of the Committee then got the floor to take it back from him by pretending that he had not finished—but in vain— Crabbe kept the floor and after twice taking the yeas and nays, the House adjourned— I went into the Senate, to give Mr Webster a remonstrance against the blood hounds, addressed to me, but directed to him—heard Mr Crittenden— Mr Boyd and Mr Melzel here this Evening.
27. V:30. Thursday

My wife had been several days somewhat indisposed but yesterday afternoon was suddenly seized with great violence, and was extremely ill, all Night with a with a stifling cough, and successive fainting fits— Doctor Thomas applied two blisters last Night and bled her this morning— She was afterwards partially relieved— I was up till near one, this morning, and then went to bed in Mrs Smith’s chamber; she and Mrs Goode passing the Night with my wife— At 10 this morning I attended the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams Davis, Slade, Mitchell Tillinghast, Dromgoole, Worthington, Eastman— Only Nisbet absent.— We took up Mr Hoyt’s Bill for reinforcing the collection of the revenue, and went through the remainder of it from the 6th. Section; and after raising and amending it the Chairman was unanimously directed to report it to the house— Two communications from the Secretary of the Treasury were read— One enclosing a Letter from Edward Cook urgently pressing the passage of a bill to repeal the exemption of pins from duty.— After various dilatory movements, the question was finally taken, and the Bill failed by a tie— Adams, Slade, Tillinghast and Mitchell ayes—and Dromgoole, Worthington, Davis and Eastman, nays— Nisbet if he had been present would have voted with them— The other communication from the Secretary was with enclosures proposing a repeal of the drawback upon exported sugars— The consideration of which and of all other matters before the Committee was postponed till next Monday.— In the House, Krabbe of Alabama had the floor on the New-Jersey election debate— I asked him to allow me to present a Report and Documents from the Smithsonian bequest Bill Committee— He said that with the general consent of the house, if no objection were made, he would readily yield me the floor for that purpose— Turney of Tennessee objected, and I could not report my bill— Jones the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means fared no better— Krabbe spoke till the hour elapsed; when the orders of the day. A call of the house was moved and refused by yeas and naystoThen they refused to take up the orders of the daytoKrabbe then resumed his Speech and continued till past 4. O’Clock. When he finished, Medill of Ohio took the floor and moved an adjournment; which was carried— They have now determined to force the 5 counter-feit members into the house without waiting for the testimony which the Committee of Elections have given the parties time to take in New-Jersey. I rode home In the evening a Mr Webster a book pedlar from Hartford, and Dr Thomas—
28. V:15. Friday

Morning visit from Mr John Connell, with a young man named Charles Blight, not the petitioner on behalf of the heirs of Robert Fulton but a relative of that family.— Also from Mr Pettrich the Sculptor, who invited me to his Studio where he has his fisherman’s daughter, and a young hunter executed in marble.—and which he said General Keim had bespoken— Keim a patron of the arts! Pettrich told me that he had executed a Colossal Statue of Washington, and several Busts, from the Quarry of marble near Frederick, in Maryland of which he had spoken to me two years ago as just discovered by him— He says it has since been explored— It is found to be one solid rock, of such extent that it will furnish an inexhaustible supply of marble superior in quality to the finest of Carrara.— My wife is still confined to her bed, with a racking Catarrhal cough.— Mrs Smith went to bed sick last Night, and between one and 2 this morning I left the Bed chamber, and made my couch of the Sopha in my chamber, which Mrs Goods had occupied— She went in to Mrs. Adams— I wasted the morning in Newspaper reading. At the House William Medill of Ohio, a member of the Committee of Elections had the floor; and after another abortive attempt of John W.
