Jones to get the rules suspended to six to-morrow, and every day after except Monday for the Treasury note Bill, made a speech of about four hours, chiefly of invective upon the Governor and Council of New-Jersey— He reproduced all the ex parte Documents which Duncan had read before the case was referred to the Committee of Elections; and assumed for the first time, that where as in New-Jersey the elections are held by ballot, there can be no proof that any votes admitted were illegal— And this will ultimately settle the question— He said further, that it had been the common practice of receiving votes of unnaturalized foreigners— Aaron V. Brown of Tennessee, after a short Speech, moved the Previous Question.— Fillmore had moved as an amendment to Cave Johnson’s amendment the words lawful, before evidence; and to strike out the word forthwith, from the Instructions to the Committee to report—he finally withdrew the motion to strike out forthwith, and the first question was on the word lawful—96 to 96. carried by the casting vote of the Speaker— Then came the question on Cave Johnson’s amendment thus amended. Carried 103 to 90—and the resolution as amended was carried without taking the yeas and nays, and almost without a negative vote— Briggs then moved to adjourn—over till Monday— After a long struggle, and a count by tellers to take the question by yeas and nays, when decided to be so taken, the motion was rejected 62 to 93. and close to 8. O’Clock the House adjourned— Thomas was there and walked with me home— It is now clear that the commissioned members from New Jersey will fail to prove the illegality of the votes by which their competitors had the majority of all the votes delivered; and that for this failure the adversary members will be forced upon the house and the Country— As usual, the whig absentees from the house, have left the field in possession of the enemy.
29. IV:45. Saturday—

My wife is partially relieved from the severity of her illness, but cannot yet leave her bed. My own Catarrhal Cough hangs obstinately upon me.— I had business at the Pension Office to transact this morning but Mr Alexander H. Everett came in, last from Boston, and kept me in conversation till the time of attendance at the House— He has actually been appointed to go to the Island of the Havanna (Cuba) to investigate the charges against the Consul Trist; and make report; A sorry work— To whitewash the very body of corruption— At the House the Speaker commenced the day by calling for Reports from Committees. The Committee of Claims alone, consumed upwards of an hour in presenting Bills, and unfavourable reports— The latter were laid on the table, and some of them ordered to be printed— The Bills were read twice by their titles, and referred to the Committee of the whole House, and made the order of the day for to-morrow; the general formula even when the morrow comes on Sunday, and there is no sitting of the house. It means the first chance that may turn up in the Chaos of public business; or that the influence and importunity of the Member having charge of it may bring to bear upon the House— The Committee of Commerce was then called, and their Chairman Curtis presented several Reports; but upon the approach of 2. O’Clock John W. Jones called for the orders of the day— A feeble effort was made to take up private business, but Jones moved a suspension of the Rules to take up, the Bill for continuing the Office of Commissioner of Pensions, and for transferring to him the Navy Pension fund— CarriedtoGarret Davis of Kentucky, made a flaming retrenchment Speech, in support of Proffit’s motion to reduce the Salary of the Commissioner from 3000 to 2500 dollars—a hack hobby of new members from the West.— While he was speaking Burch came, and brought to my notice the transfer of the Navy Pension fund from the Navy Department to the Commissioner of Pensions—which he thought the Officers of the Navy would dislike— The Bill came from the Senate— I found on consulting Mr Lawrence and Mr Grinnell that it had not been referred to the Committee of ways and means, and it has not been printed— Jones afterwards came and shewed me the passage in the annual report of the Secretary of the Navy to the President p. 536 on which the bill is founded— The house adjourned about 4. O’Clock— Mr and Mrs Frye were here after dinner— And Mr Hand this Evening— Trouble in the 2d. Presbyterian Church— Mr Wood is a Congregationalist, and was elected by Congregationalist Pew-holders against the will of the Presbyterians 40 of whom have signed a protest against his election— I told Mr Hand that in authorising Mr Wilson to say that I freely assented to the election of Mr Wood, I had supposed the election was unanimous, and would neither take part in nor contribute to any discord or dissension in the Church.—
